Title: Proving that a convergent sequence has a unique limit
Content: Is the following method wrong? Let { $a_n$ } be a convergent sequence Assume $$ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \{a_n \} = L \text{ and}  \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \{a_n \} = M$$ $$L-M = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \{a_n \} - \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \{a_n \} = L-L =0$$ $$ \therefore  L=M$$
AcceptedAnswer: If you have already proved the relevant result about the limit of a sum, or difference, it is OK. But the result about uniqueness of limits that you are trying to prove comes typically quite early, immediately after the definition. So we give a fairly detailed proof. Suppose to the contrary that $L\ne M$. Let $\epsilon=\frac{|L-M|}{10}$. There is an $N_1$ such that if $n\gt N_1$ then $|a_n-L|\lt \epsilon$. There is an $N_2$ such that if $n\gt N_2$ then $|a_n-M|\lt \epsilon$. Let $N=\max(N_1,N_2)$. If $n\gt N$ then $|a_n-L|\lt \epsilon$ and $|a_n-M|\lt \epsilon$. But then by the Triangle inequality $|L-M|\le |a_n-L|+|M-a_n|\lt \frac{2}{10}|L-M|$. This is impossible. Hence the assumption $L\ne M$ is false and  $L=M$. Remark: The basic intuition is pretty simple. After a while $a_n$ is very close to $L$. After a while it is very close to $M$. That's not possible. The $\epsilon$ stuff made  this geometric intuition arithmetical.
